comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Thanks. They are from Robert Pool's collection. Check out his site, he's got tons of interesting stuff all relating to Glasgow....enought to fill a museum & archive!!
Stuart.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Interesting related piece on the Ask about Ireland website, The Waterford News - 28th of July 1916 This building is number 9 Henrietta Street, Waterford Street View

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Can't thank you enough for this one, Paul! It had been annoying me that we didn't know where it was. Found a lovely snippet on Waterford in the Seaman's Handbook for Shore Leave from 1919:
Sailors' Homes, etc. British and Foreign Sailors' Society, David Beatty, Sailors' Rest, 9 Henrietta Street (No board or lodging, but Recreation Rooms, Bath Rooms, Coffee Bar, free Literature. Sailors are sent to Ossory Hotel, Gladstone St., two shillings nightly, free Library and amusements); Soldiers' and Sailors' Home, Adelphi Terrace (Board and lodging).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]I'm a little surprised the building is still standing considering all the development that has gone on in the area. I think there is a good chance this photo was also taken in Henrietta Street
